content.description: This climb is pretty short.  It starts with an undercling layback aiming left for a sloping rail.  From there it goes straight up following crimps and jugs up top.
content.protection: I used a yellow  C3 at the bottom and a clear alien up higher.  The bottom could have been protected with a #6 camalot, and the top could be protected with a 2.5 tech friend or #2 camalot.  You could protect again at the jugs up top, but they look a little loose.
content.location: The route is located on the secondary face. To get here walk left from the parking lot around the main area.  Then take another left. (Don Quixote wall would be the right) The climb is on the left side of the wall and the start, marked with the undercling traverse is pretty obvious.

content.description: A nice looking thin crack on a slabby face.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2". Natural anchor on top and easy walk-off.
content.location:
Far left on the Secondary Face which is behind Main Wall and 100 ft. east of Don Quixote Wall. The easiest access is from the gravel parking lot walk straight back and look for the rock bands on the left. Stay low.

You will run into Diamond Crack right before the access ramp that puts you on top of Secondary Face.

content.description: Although short,this is a very good quality route. Most will find it stiff for a 5.8. But the good news is, if you're comfortabe leading all the 5.8's at Minnehaha, you'll probably have no problem with old school trad areas like Eldorado. There are some tough moves right off the ground, another crux midway, and an exhilirating roof finish, which is not as hard as it looks.
content.protection: Pro to 2", or just a set of stoppers.
content.location: The obvious right facing corner capped by a roof in the middle of the Secondary Face. The Secondary Face is 100 ft. West of Don Quixote face. From the gravel lot go straight back and bear left, while staying low. In a couple hundred feet you'll see the Secondary Face to your left.

content.description: A fun climb that has you switching between jams, face holds and stemming. A little bit of everything and really good for a short 5.7. New leaders may find it feels committing for 5.7, but it protects well.
content.protection: gear to 3". 2 bolts with hangers at the top. webbing or slings needed for TR. easy walk-off.
content.location:
Back Tree Crack is on the Secondary Face. Go around the main face, cross the hollow, and 100 ft. to the west you'll find the Secondary Face, which holds five 11-ish bolted routes and five or six good gear climbs.

On the far right side is an obvious right leaning hand crack- this is Back Tree Crack.

content.description: A nice looking crack on a slabby face.
content.protection: Mostly small nuts. Offset brass helpful. Small cam for the roof.
content.location:
Far left on the Secondary Face which is behind Main Wall and 100 ft. east of Don Quixote Wall. The easiest access is from the gravel parking lot walk straight back and look for the rock bands on the left. Stay low.

You will run into 2 cracks on a slabby face right before the access ramp that puts you on top of Secondary Face.

content.description: Good but hard and crimpy down low. WTF hard up high. Pretty stout for 5.11. The crux comes after the roof. I couldn't link it.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. no chains.
content.location: 1st route to the left of The Prow. Located on the Secondary Face, 100 ft. to the West of the Main Crag.

content.description:
I think this is the best sport lead at Minnehaha, and one of the best 10d's in the area. It is also quite a safe lead; unusual for Minne. There used to be a scary runout to the chains, but a bolt has been added since Marty's book came out.

The Prow requires some long moves to good crimps and has jugs when you need them to clip. The crux is between the second and third bolt. First bolt is sort of high, so pay attention.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a two bolt anchor. no chains, easy walk off.
content.location:
The Prow is on the Secondary Face. Go around the main face, cross the hollow, and 100 ft. to the west you'll find the Secondary Face, which holds five 11-ish bolted routes and five or six good gear climbs.

On the far right side is an obvious right leaning hand crack, Back Tree Crack (5.7). The Prow is the blocky, steep arete immediately to the left.

content.description: Bouldery with the business at the top.
content.protection: Bolts, lower off at the top.
content.location: Sport pitch to the right of The Hooker
